7.19.text: Simple plant-based sprays are a simple way to keep the garden healthy

12.04.text: and this nettle tea spray is super rich in life-giving nutrients - iron, magnesium, calcium and potassium

20.28.text: It helps your plants to grow strongly, which means they are less attractive to pests.

25.36.text: Collect the nettle leaves and stems when the nettle begins to flower

29.74.text: this is when the nutrient levels are at their highest

32.82.text: To make the nettle concentrate soak 4 ounces, or 100 grams, of nettle leaves

38.04.text: in 1 3/4 pints, or 1 litre, of boiling water.

45.92.text: Strain and squeeze out all the liquid.

49.64.text: To make the tea, dilute by using 1 part nettle concentrate in 5 - 20 parts water.

56.56.text: If your plants are weak and need a boost, go for a stronger concentration.

60.91.text: If you're just doing a general spray to keep the garden ticking over

64.22.text: go for a more dilute one.

67.40.text: Plant teas benefit from being dynamized

70.68.text: the aeration helps them to stick better, and makes it easier for plants

74.16.text: and the soil to take up the nutrients in the liquid.

77.14.text: A 10 to 20 minute stir is fine.

79.90.text: See the other videos in our playlist to learn how to dynamize biodynamic sprays.
